sn14.13:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.
sn14.13:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
sn14.13:2.1: “Mendicants, an element gives rise to a perception, a view, and a thought.”
sn14.13:2.2: When he said this, Venerable Kaccāna said to the Buddha,
sn14.13:2.4: those who are not fully awakened Buddhas, there is a view that they are in fact fully awakened Buddhas. Due to what does this view appear?”
sn14.13:3.1: “It’s a mighty thing, Kaccāna, the element of ignorance.
sn14.13:3.2: An inferior element gives rise to inferior perceptions, inferior views, inferior thoughts, inferior intentions, inferior aims, inferior wishes, an inferior person, and inferior speech.
sn14.13:3.3: One explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals the inferior.
sn14.13:3.4: I say that their rebirth is inferior.
sn14.13:4.1: A middling element gives rise to middling perceptions, middling views, middling thoughts, middling intentions, middling aims, middling wishes, a middling person, and middling speech.
sn14.13:4.2: One explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals the middling.
sn14.13:4.3: I say that their rebirth is middling.
sn14.13:5.1: A superior element gives rise to superior perceptions, superior views, superior thoughts, superior intentions, superior aims, superior wishes, a superior person, and superior speech.
sn14.13:5.2: One explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals the superior.
sn14.13:5.3: I say that their rebirth is superior.”
